msgSnippet: And if mocking isn t what you are after, then sqlunit is an alternative to consider in addition to dbunit. SqlUnit is often attractive if you wish to be

Subject: Re: [junit] To test a class calling a stored procedure
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=215576703


And if mocking isn't what you are after, then sqlunit is an alternative
to consider in addition to dbunit. SqlUnit is often attractive if you
wish to be ant-centric (doesn't require programming) and DbUnit if you
wish to be more Java-centric.

Cheers, Paul.

J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> dans wrote:
> 
> 
>>Is there a method to populate the database from the junit other than the 
>>dbunit . The junit should be such that it doesnt fail, as i am passing a 
>>parameter to my class method eg a telephone number and my unit test will 
>>be successful only if this is found in the table and if it is not in the 
>>table then my test fails which i want to avoid .
> 
> 
> If your test uses the real database, then I don't see how you can avoid
> this situation: you need the real data to be there.
> 
> If you only want to verify that your code invokes the stored procedure 
> correctly, you can mock the JDBC API. This allows you to check the name 
> of the stored procedure you try to invoke as well as the parameters you 
> bind to it. This would avoid the need for using a real database and 
> having real test data in there.
> 
> 
>>Also if i throw a sql exception i want to test that too which i am 
>>unable to do right now .
> 
> 
> You can fake the JDBC API to throw any SQLException and verify that your 
> code correctly handles that exception.
> 
> 
>>Can anybody through some light on this
> 
> 
> I discuss this in detail in Chapter 10 of _JUnit Recipes_.
> 
> Good luck.
subject: Re: [junit] To test a class calling a stored procedure
